body.p: The following text is transcribed in all capital letters to represent the title of the article as it is depicted in the obituary. COLORED PASTOR HERE 22 YEARS SUCCUMBS

Rev.Reverend J. Milton Waldron of Shiloh
Church Was Active in Wel-
fare Movements.

Rev.Reverend J. Milton Waldron, one of the
best known colored clergymen in this
city, for 22 years pastor of Shiloh Bap-
tist Church, Ninth and TPossible typographical error. Location is recorded at "9th & P Streets". See "Biographical/Historical Information." Shiloh Baptist Church (Washington, D.C.) records, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books Division, The New York Public Library. streets, died
at his home, 1334 V street, today after
a long illness. He retired from the
active ministry about two years ago.

Born in Lynchburg, Va.Virginia, May 19, 1863,
Rev.Reverend Waldron was educated at Lincoln
University in Pennsylvania and at the
Newton Theological Seminary in Massa-
chusetts.

His first pastorate was at the Berean
Baptist Church here, where he served
nearly two years. Subsequently he was
in Jacksonville, Fla.Florida, 15 years as pastor,
and while there was instrumental in
building two larges churches. During his time in Jacksonville, Waldron was pastor at Bethel Baptist Institutional Church. See “Opening Exercises of the Bethel Baptist Institutional Church: Jacksonville, Florida April 23-30 A.D. 1905,” Eartha M.M. White Collection, University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives. UNF Digital Commons, https://digitalcommons.unf.edu/eartha_materials/22/. Accessed 19 July 2020. Leaving
Jacksonville, he came back to this city
to become pastor of Shiloh Baptist
Church, serving there continuously un-
til his retirement.

Interested for many years in the
betterment of the living conditions of
his race as well as general improve-
ments to the National Capital, Rev.Reverend Mr.
Waldron was for a number of years
president of the old Alley Improvement
Association and in more recent years
had been a member of Housing Im-
provement Association. Through him
the colored day nursery, formerly locat-
ed at New Jersey avenue and Pierce
street, was established.

He is survived by his widow,
Mrs. Martha M. Waldron; his father, Isaac
Waldron, and several brothers and
sisters.

The funeral will be held in the Shiloh
Baptist Church Monday afternoon at
1one o'clock. Internment will be in Harmony
Cemetery.
